pageContext.claim: “[Because of catch and release, immigrants] go and they live in our country. Then they're supposed to come back in three years for a court case, and about 2 percent come back, as you know.”
pageContext.analysis: Justice Department data show 60 percent to 75 percent of non-detained migrants have attended their immigration court proceedings. For the specific group of migrants Trump was addressing, asylum-seekers, data suggests the return rate is even higher. The data for a program that Trump ended in June shows participants had a 100 percent attendance record at court hearings. They also had a 99 percent rate of check-ins and appointments with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, according to a report by the Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General.
